description: 1 print (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 36.8 x 76.1 cm (whole image), 36.4 x 25.4 cm (left panel), 36.8 x 25.1 cm (center panel), 36.5 x 25.6 cm (right panel) | Ukiyo-e triptych print showing a snowy landscape with a woman brandishing a broom and a man holding an umbrella.

item.access_advisory: Restricted access: Materials extremely fragile; please use online digital images.
item.call_number: FP 2 - JPD, no. 2215 a, b, c (E size) [P&P]
medium: 1 print (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 36.8 x 76.1 cm (whole image), 36.4 x 25.4 cm (left panel), 36.8 x 25.1 cm (center panel), 36.5 x 25.6 cm (right panel)
mediums: 1 print (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 36.8 x 76.1 cm (whole image), 36.4 x 25.4 cm (left panel), 36.8 x 25.1 cm (center panel), 36.5 x 25.6 cm (right panel)
notes: Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Material Culture. This triptych is a joint work by Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) and Utagawa Hiroshige (1797-1858). The signature "Painted by Toyokuni" (Toyokuni-ga) appears on the left and right prints, while the center piece is signed "Brush of Hiroshige" (Hiroshige hitsu). The careful recording of physical objects, typical of Ukiyo-e, is in abundance here including the elaborate dress of the male figure delicately holding an umbrella above him, and the female figure elegantly brandishing a broom.
Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06.

Joint work by Utagawa Kunisada and Utagawa Hiroshige. Signature Toyokuni-ga (painted by Toyokuni) is on the left and right panels. Signature Hiroshige hitsu (brush of Hiroshige) is on the center panel.
Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress).
Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 24, p. 54-55.
Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001.
Preliminary catalog record: are these the correct artists? Check with KB

rights:
The Library of Congress does not own rights to material in its collections. Therefore, it does not license or charge permission fees for use of such material and cannot grant or deny permission to publish or otherwise distribute the material.

Ultimately, it is the researcher's obligation to assess copyright or other use restrictions and obtain permission from third parties when necessary before publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the Library's collections.

For information about reproducing, publishing, and citing material from this collection, as well as access to the original items, see: Japanese Fine Prints and Drawings, pre-1915 - Rights and Restrictions Information
